title: 109_s1037
content: The "Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005" requires disclosure of financial relationships between brokers and mutual fund companies. The "Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005" mandates brokers to disclose compensation received for transactions involving open-end mutual funds registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940. The disclosure should include the amount of compensation and any other relevant information determined by the Commission. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005 requires brokers to disclose any payments from investment advisers for promoting open-end company securities to customers at the completion of the transaction, excluding disclosures in registration statements or prospectuses. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005 mandates the Commission to establish final rules within a year to enforce disclosure requirements for brokerage commissions related to open-end company securities. Disclosure forms must adhere to Commission rules. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005 requires the Commission to enforce disclosure of brokerage commissions for open-end company securities, including the inclusion of brokerage commissions in disclosure of fees and expenses for registration statements and other filings with the Commission. SEC. 3. MUTUAL FUND GOVERNANCE. Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 regarding Independent Fund Boards, including changes to board composition requirements. Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 requires independent directors to be evaluated for relationships that may compromise their independence. Independent directors must not have material business or familial relationships that could impair their independence. No action by the board of directors can be taken without the vote of independent directors. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires independent directors to establish a committee responsible for nominating board members and setting qualification standards. Disclosure of these standards is mandatory in the registration statement of the company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires independent directors to establish a committee responsible for nominating board members and setting qualification standards. Section 2(a)(19) of the Act is amended to include definitions of interested persons, including individuals who have served as officers, directors, or employees of investment advisers or principal underwriters within the past 10 fiscal years. The Investment Company Act of 1940 mandates independent directors to form a committee for nominating board members. It includes definitions of interested persons, such as those who have served as officers, directors, or employees of investment advisers or underwriters in the past 10 fiscal years. Additionally, individuals who have been associated with significant service providers to registered investment companies within the last 5 fiscal years are also considered. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires independent directors to establish a committee for nominating board members. It defines interested persons as those with a material business relationship, close familial ties to affiliated persons, or for reasons determined by the Commission. Changes include increasing the number of individuals in clause (iv) from two to five and specifying that any natural person who is a member can be considered. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires independent directors to establish a committee for nominating board members. Interested persons are defined as those with a material business relationship, close familial ties to affiliated persons, or for reasons determined by the Commission. Any natural person who is a member of a class determined by the Commission to lack independence due to certain relationships is included. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires independent directors to establish a committee for nominating board members. The Securities and Exchange Commission will issue final rules defining the term 'significant service provider' within 270 days of the Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005 enactment. The definition will include the investment adviser and principal underwriter. SEC. 4. FINANCIAL LITERACY AMONG MUTUAL FUND INVESTORS STUDY. The Securities and Exchange Commission will conduct a study to identify the level of financial literacy among investors purchasing shares of open-end companies, the necessary information for sound financial decisions, methods to increase transparency in transactions, existing efforts to educate investors, and a strategy to improve investor behavior. The Securities and Exchange Commission will submit a report to the Senate and House of Representatives one year after enacting the Act, regarding a study on financial literacy among investors and strategies to improve investor behavior. SEC. 5. STUDY REGARDING MUTUAL FUND ADVERTISING. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on mutual fund advertising, including regulatory requirements, marketing practices, consumer impact, and recommendations for improving investor protections. A report on the study results must be submitted within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The study results must be reported to the Senate's Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs and the House of Representatives' Committee on Financial Services. SEC. 6. POINT-OF-SALE DISCLOSURE. In General, broker disclosures in mutual fund transactions require brokers to disclose compensation details to purchasers of investment company shares. This includes the source and amount of compensation received, both in dollars and as a percentage of assets. The broker must disclose compensation details in mutual fund transactions, including the percentage of assets and comparative information on amounts received by brokers. Compensation includes direct or indirect payments from investment advisers. The broker must disclose compensation details in mutual fund transactions to promote sales of securities of a registered investment company. Disclosures must be made in a timely manner for evaluation before engaging in the transaction, and cannot be exclusively in registration statements or prospectuses. Commission has authority over these disclosures. The Commission has the authority to promulgate final rules within one year of the Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005. National securities associations must issue rules requiring brokers to have a fiduciary duty and act in the best interests of clients within the same timeframe. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2005 requires brokers to act in the best interests of clients, fully disclose conflicts of interest, and provide this information before and annually after giving investment advice.
